lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen and identify key details about Campbell and his teddy bears by choosing correct answers (e.g., multiple choice).
supportStrategies: (Listening) Play video in short parts. Ask: “What toy? Who has it?” Students choose between two.
stretchStrategies: After the video, list actions Campbell did (e.g. played, hugged). Students draw their favourite teddy activity and say: “I play with my teddy.” or “I hug my teddy.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can identify how Campbell feels about his teddy bears and say one way their own toy is the same or different.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Show SB image. Ask: “What’s the same/different from your school?”
stretchStrategies: After the video, list actions Campbell did (e.g. played, hugged). Students draw their favourite teddy activity and say: “I play with my teddy.” or “I hug my teddy.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can think critically about what things make them happy.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Critical Thinking) Draw 2-column chart: “Campbell’s toys / My toys.” Students add ideas.
stretchStrategies: After the video, list actions Campbell did (e.g. played, hugged). Students draw their favourite teddy activity and say: “I play with my teddy.” or “I hug my teddy.”

items: VYL: colours do not map onto one another (blue/green = blue)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
